headline: Halupki (Stuffed Cabbage)
description: This Ukrainian-style stuffed cabbage recipe features a hearty ground beef, pork, and rice filling topped with a tasty sweet-sour tomato sauce.
name: Halupki (Stuffed Cabbage)

recipeInstructions.text: Place cabbage in a stockpot; pour over enough water to cover. Add 1/4 teaspoon salt; bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Turn cabbage every 2 to 3 minutes; transfer any leaves that separate from cabbage into a strainer to drain and cool. Continue to boil until all the leaves have cooked, about 15 minutes. Reserve 1 1/2 cups of cabbage cooking water. Cut out the tough, thick center ribs of any large cabbage leaves with a sharp knife.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).

Mix ground beef, ground pork, cooked rice, eggs, onion, fresh parsley, garlic powder, salt, and pepper in a large bowl until combined. Lay 1 cabbage leaf on a flat surface; place 1 heaping tablespoon of filling at the base of a cabbage leaf. Overlap with the bottom of the leaf; fold in side edges and roll up.
Repeat with remaining large cabbage leaves and filling.
Cut any leftover cabbage leaves into pieces and place in the bottom of a roasting pan. Layer stuffed cabbage rolls on top.
Combine tomato sauce, reserved cabbage water, white vinegar, and white sugar in a bowl; pour mixture over cabbage rolls. Cover roasting pan with aluminum foil.
Bake in the preheated oven until filling is cooked through and sauce has thickened, about 2 1/2 hours. Baste stuffed cabbage rolls every hour.

review.reviewBody: Jillian: Can’t thank you enough for the delicious recipe. I have been buying my Halupki at the local European Market but now I can make them myself. Not quite as good as my Grandmother’s but she cooked on a coal fired stove and had fresh meat from the livestock as well as tomatoes and herbs from the garden. Oh those good old days.
Can’t wait to make it this weekend! It’s looks just like the recipe my mom use to make
Made these for my husband after making American Stuffed cabbage and he said these tasted just like his Moms/Grandma's. I'm making again for him to take home to serve his Mom! Thank you! :)
Very easy to make! I did have a lot of meat mix left so I made a meatloaf. I'm not sure if I measured wrong or what but any recipe that gets me two dinners out of it is ok in my book.
delicious but i put a bag of sauerkraut over top before baking unrinsed
I use riced cauliflower instead of white rice, less time to cook and more flavor
This is the best! We've tried several different recipes, this one is the winner. Everyone loved them and the (red gravy), the sauce is great on mashed potatoes.

My wife of 10 years was raised on Polish foods and for quite some time, had a hard time finding an authentic Halupki recipe. Have made this a couple dozen times since discovering it and she absolutely loves it. Only do a couple minor modifications I've found enhance the recipe over time: I use fresh minced garlic rather than garlic powder, and I use 8oz of Campbells tomato soup (uncooked, out of the can) and 24oz tomato sauce. These both add a little more flavor and texture, and make a little extra sauce for the mashed potatoes that pair perfectly with this recipe.

I have made several recipes for cabbage rolls trying to mimic my great grandmother’s recipe, and I keep coming back to this one because it is the closest and best. A couple of very minor changes I make are to grate a half an onion right into the meat mixture. I also use fresh pressed garlic, cayenne pepper and some nutmeg which I mix into the beaten eggs before combining it all. Otherwise I make this exactly as written. My family also enjoyed them with mashed potatoes and we will again tonight!

love love these...thanks for your great recipe. used a large grated carrot, a grated zucchini and fresh garlic. basmati rice was all I had and it worked well. made 18 rolls with 1 head of cabbage and 1 lb ea lean ground beef and pork. Froze some but they won't last long!

Followed the recipe exactly...though i did forget to line the baking dish with cabbage lol...thanx beer!! Luckily it didnt matter i just used the extra leaves to cover the top of the rolls instead. Still turned out stupendous. I'll definitely be making this again. Actually i had leftover meat mixture and sauce, so i went and bought another small cabbage and the remainders cooking right now lol. Great recipe Grandma!!
I took the advice of Emmlee..we put the rolls on a bed of imported kraut and I also ground Pork shoulder and seasoned it.. It was yummy
Delicious - love putting cut-up cabbage in the bottom of the pan as it uses all the cabbage and is a wonderful way to eat cabbage.
It is delicious. Used brown rice instead.

This was my first time making cabbage rolls and they turned out great! My husband ate 8 of them! 

I did make some adjustments to use ingredients I already had on hand and will probably do the same next time. I used white wine vinegar, 2lb. ground beef and 1lb. ground italian sausage, and I used brown sugar instead of white. I also added 2-15oz cans of diced tomatoes to the sauce and seasoned with salt and pepper after it was done cooking. One thing I would change next time is the cook time. I have a convection oven so I reduced the temperature to 325, but 2.5 hours was still a bit too long. Next time I’ll check them at 2 and 2.25 hours. Thanks for sharing your family recipe!

I love this! My grandma always made it, but I never had the recipe. I added 1thing to make it more like hers.

She always added Sauerkraut on top before the tomatoes sauce. I did omit the vinegar with this addition. Super delicious! Just like grandma’s!
Wonderful, the whipped potatoes made a perfect meal.

I have this recipe bookmarked and it's the only one I use anymore! This is by far the closest thing to the ones my great grandmother use to make and my whole family loves them so much I have to double the recipe every time I make it. 
I am very much a cook to taste home chef and there has never been a recipe I haven't "improved" to my own taste except this one. It is authentic and perfect just the way it is. We serve them over mashed potatoes and they are the best. I have never tried to freeze them before cooking them and wonder if anyone has and if so, how long to bake them from frozen if you don't precooked them. Thank you for sharing this recipe. Even my grandmother approves and she always loved her mother's cabbage rolls the best. (My Nona didn't write down her recipes and until now no one could duplicate it. Not even my grandmother)

I’ve made this twice now and it’s great! This second time I used Swiss chard instead of cabbage and couldn’t be happier with it. The only other changes I made were crushed tomatoes instead of tomato sauce and cider vinegar instead of white. Delicious!!
Excellent recipe even doubled.

I love this recipe for cabbage rolls but rarely make it due to the prep time. I have tried the "unstuffed" versions but they are not the same. 
This time, I boiled and prepared my cabbage leaves yesterday, drained on a towel and packed them into a storage container with a paper towel on top and placed in the refrigerator overnight. Cooked the rice and placed in the fridge. I wasn't sure the prepped cabbage leaves would be easy to roll today, but they were! All I had to do today was make the filling, roll and make the sauce.

Delicious recipe! I had to tweak a couple things due to not having everything in my pantry. I used all ground beef. I had to use lemon juice instead of vinegar. I also used brown sugar instead of white. I had a carrot that needed used so I grated 1/2 of it into the meat mixture. My family loved it!
Instead of using sugar and vinegar, I lined the bottom of the pan with sauerkraut and chopped tomatoes. Mixed more sauerkraut, chopped tomatoes and tomato soup for the top. Delicious!
This is exactly how my Slovak mom made them. They are delicious!!
This recipe was easy also very good,did a few things different threw some of my sauce in with the meat.Used basil and flat Italian fresh from garden,thanks
Yummy, made me think of grandmas. Time consuming but well worth it. Perpared and baked half froze other half for another meal. So glad found this recipe. Thanks
Absolutely loved this recipe !!! And so did my husband and children . Thank you for sharing this delicious and simple to follow recipe .

Bland. 

You need to up the salt and black pepper a lot to start.
.

This turns out to be a rather large recipe, so I'd suggest either using some leaves from an additional cabbage or making sure to get a very large head. I used extra leaves since I happened to have 2 heads of cabbage. What I didn't have, was 1-1/2 lbs of ground pork; I only had about 1/2 lb, so I made up the difference with 1/2 lb beef and 1/2 lb. bacon (yes, BACON), which I cut into tiny pieces (uncooked) and added to the rest. The other alteration I made was to use tomato paste instead of tomato sauce because I wanted a richer sauce, but I diluted it with about 2-1/2 cups of cabbage water just to increase the volume. I ended up with about 20 wraps, and I baked them for 1-1/4 hours (the first 45 min. at 375F, then turned down to 350F for the last 30 min,). They turned out fabulous. The only thing my wife commented was that she wanted even more sauce to put on at a topping at the end. I think I must have eaten like 5 or 6 -- couldn't stop. Thanks for the recipe!

What a great comfort food. It went great with the mashed potatoes as recommended. Even my 10 year old grandson like this dish - picky eater. I used half canned diced tomatoes as I did not have enough sauce - worked fine. I had left over meat, so put in a mini pan for meatloaf, poured some of the sauce over and cooked off with the rolls for less time. Use for sandwiches or whatever. Easy enough to make, not to much of a mess to clean up. Will make again and again!
These came out quite well. I used tomato soup for the sauce instead of the one you make in the recipe. I think adding more rice would make this recipe even better.

Two changes. The recipe was for 6 so adjust accordingly. Instead of tomato sauce I used a 15 oz can of dices tomatoes. All of the liquid and half of the tomatoes went into the sauce. The other half was added to the stuffing mixture. Also I added 1/4 cup of ricotta cheese for flavor. UMMM and AHHH were the comments.

This was the first time I have made cabbage rolls - this was soooooooo good. I followed the receipe, but added some smoked paprika to the meat mixuture. I had some salad and crusty bread with this, would definitely make this again.

I made it with what I had on hand: ground turkey. Seasoned with salt pepper onion garlic parsley paprika. I followed the instructions but I put it in my pressure cooker for 20. Minutes. . It was delicious. Melt in your mouth good. Will definitely make it again.

This was great! I pulled the cabbage leaves off before boiling; it wasn’t that hard. I made 12 rolls. Added paprika and scotch bonnet pepper to the meat mixture. Are it with sour cream and chive mashed potatoes which complemented it perfectly. I don’t think it would have been as good without the potatoes

I have always made mine in crockpot with tomatoes and sauerkraut (a must in this dish). I also core cabbage before immersing in water; and slice off the spine on each cabbage leaf after cooking. Cabbage stuffed with raw meat and cooked rice mixture. One of my all time favorites!! Always make extra, worth the time.
Excellent!
FANTASTIC exactly as written. I loved the sauce so much! This dish really does go well with creamy mashed potatoes. This is a keeper- thanks Jillian for submitting it!
First time making stuff cabbage, took longer than I expected, but worth it. I think next time I will add a little bit more sugar. It was very good.

My husband loved this and he is a picky eater. I used fresh tomatoes that were canned from the garden this summer. Organic large head of cabbage and fresh parsley. Fresh is best. I normally tweak recipes but this is perfect the way it is. It is time consuming to make but well worth it. I will make again.

We really loved this dish! I did make some alterations for our taste (I used brown sugar instead of white, I used minute rice and added it to the meat mixture uncooked, I also added 2/3c finely diced carrot and 1-tBSP of Worcestershire sauce. I also used dry minced onion instead of fresh diced. My meat mixture was 2lb of pork & 1lb of ground turkey) and they turned out great. 100% will make again!

This was a fairly simple dish to make (other than those blessed cabbage leaves, but that's a given). I really enjoyed the taste and I would definitely make it again, with the exception of adding some additional sauce or other material to loosen up the filling just a little. It comes out very compact (good for stuffing) but really dry. I will give it another try, perhaps with a little extra tomato sauce mixed in, and hope it will show all it's promise!
Grew up eating this and never had any recipe that tasted so close to my busha’s as this!!! Very traditional taste!

Excellent! The things I did differently was, I did not use 12oz of cabbage water in the tomato soup, Yes I used tomato soup (2 large cans) however, I did use the water to thin the soup to my liking. The other thing I didn't do was, I didn't add sugar to the soup, but i did add a little vinegar. Great recipe!

I made this recipe and it was EXACTLY as my Mother ( Italian by birth), made it when we were growing up in Pittsburgh, Pa.
She added a can (or bag) of sauerkraut to the recipe, which made it that much better !!
Mike P. / Robinson Township, Pa.
I use Napa cabbage instead. The leaves are more tender, extremely easy to cut and roll making things go much faster. I also add 1/2 pound of cooked finely chopped bacon for an extra bump of flavor.
I like to add sauerkraut on top. Gives it a kick.

I made exactly as written and it lacked flavor. I should have known that a ½ teaspoon of salt and pepper was not enough for an entire pan of rolls. I also hesitated to add the cabbage water and should have listened to my instincts. The sauce was way too thin and was almost tasteless. I've since read other recipes that do not add water but also add a few tablespoons of the tomato sauce to the meat mixture which I think would help. keep the meat tender. I think the cooking time is too long - two hours would do it. My apologies to the author of this recipe but I would not make again.
This was great! The only change I made was to add a can of cream of mushroom soup to the sauce because we like a creamy "pink" sauce. Yum.
Super delicious! I could not get ground sausage so I used Hot Italian sausage instead. That's how I make it from now on.
This is the closest recipe I can find to my family’s recipe. We could eat halupki every day.

This recipe tasted exactly like my grandma from Ukraine used to make. I have made them a handful of times over the past 30 years but was never really satisfied with the way they turned out. This recipe however was point on!!! I will be making these regularly now. Thank you!!! Scrumotious

Excellent! I grew up with my grandmother making halupki and pierogie for dinner.
 I modify mine a bit. I layer bacon with a little tomato sauce at the bottom of a dutch oven, place the remaining cabbage leaves on that. it prevents sticking! Also, I add onions to the meat and rice, and only use ground beef (the bacon gives the pork flavor. 
 I love the suggestion of coring the cabbage before boiling! Why didn't I think of that!! 
 Great recipe.

don't use tomato sauce, use whole tomatoes , squish the tomatoes into the pot...also, don't use eggs ….ever...not in this recipe also, use a handful of sauerkraut, makes such a difference....delicious!
Hubby loved it!

WE only made 2 changes to this recipe.... the first one was I only used salt in the water for the cabbage I was cooking because we are cutting back on our salt & the 2nd change was instead of regular rice , we used Charleston red rice....... it was amazing..... it had plenty of seasonings in it.
Awesome !! Only change would be 1 lb sausage and 2 lb of beef .. otherwise this was delicious!! Just like grandma used to make
We followed this recipe with a few minor alterations. Campbell’s tomato soup, tomato paste and no vineg
The only change I made was black pepper and 1 tbls Worcestershire in the sauce.

My Italian Grandmother learned how to make halupki's after she immigrated to the U.S. by a Russian neighbor. Through much trial & error, these taste the closest to Nanny's recipe. I sub the 1&1/2 lb. pork for 1&1/2 lb. Jennie O Italian turkey sausage ...(personal preference) otherwise follow it exactly. We LOVE these, Thank you so much for sharing , Jillian!

Great recipe-- just like Baba's. Don't skimp on the tomato sauce; it really does make a difference. (A lot of cheap canned tomatoes are too acidic.) I used Cento tomato puree, and this was sooo tasty followed exactly as written. Thanks!

This Polish Girl doesn't add the egg but I do add 2 or 3 TBSP of the tomato soup to the meat mixture for a little added flavor. May be a benefit, may not be, but I've been doing it this way for years. I like it. :-) 
We also from the time I can remember, cook them slowly on top of the stove, covered with a lid. We place a dish directly on the top of the halupki to keep then from shifting while cooking. 
Thank you for this authentic recipe! It's deliciously delicious. I have made it twice already and I am making it again today. Will add a photo later too. :-)

4.7.18 A tip from years ago from the Cabbage King cookbook made me prepare my cabbage leaves differently: freeze the entire head of cabbage, then defrost, cut out the core, and cabbage leaves just fall out. Sorry, I just couldn’t see all tomato sauce, so I used 1 can each of diced tomatoes and tomato sauce. I used what was on hand which ended up being more pork than ground beef, but all tasted fine. Made these cabbage rolls in the morning, refrigerated, and then into the oven for dinner for an easy, but tasty entree. These were very, very good cabbage rolls, served with mashed potatoes and freshly-cooked apples. Definitely would make again.

These were delicious. I loved the sauce. The filling was very moist and flavorful. Will definitely make again. Only changes I made were I used fresh garlic and finely chopped onion. also added Hungarian paprika. Thanks for the recipe.

Dare I say that this was better than my buscha's. :O 
I used San Marzano tomatoes, but did everything else as is. Maybe I added a little bit more salt, too. Thank you for this recipe. My Buscha died 8 years ago, and I never got the recipe. My Polish grandma would be proud of me tonight feeding my kids this (and they devoured it!).
Tasted just like my grandmother’s!!
Tasty recipe! My only suggestion is to make extra sauce.
Just as I remembered it from my childhood!

I made this today. The ratio of meat to rice was spot on. I doubled the amount of salt pepper and spices because of a few reviews stating blandness. Didn’t have tomato sauce so I used Tomato soup (it's what I had on hand ) and omitted the sugar. This was the best stuffed cabbage I have ever made! Could never get my stuffed cabbage to taste authentic. 
The beef and pork mixture really make these rolls so tender and the rice was just enough to hold them together.
So happy for such a success! Thank you!!!

Absolutely delicious. I made it a few times the original recipe, but alter it slightly for my family (more meat, garlic powder upped a bit) and we love it. It tastes just like what my grandmother used to make. Thank you for posting this recipe and taking me back to my childhood every time I make it for my family.
I shouldn't even give it one star. I followed the recipe to the letter. It turned out so bland with these dry globs of meat rolled up in cabbage. Sorry, it is a bust as far as I am concerned.
I would suggest that you tell the cook to core the cabbage before you boil it. That makes it much easier to peel the leaves off the cabbage in boiling water.
It turned out great will make this again. Thanks for sharing!
I did it unstuffed, like lasagna style, and sprinkled flour on the meat before lettuce, like I would have done had I rolled it.
Great recipe.

I highly recommend you watch a YouTube video on how to roll these! I did one head of cabbage. Rolled a lasagna pan full and made halupki lasagna style with the rest! It makes a truck load! We froze the rolled and ate the lasagna style.
Absolutely amazing!! My go-to for the future for sure. Thanks so much to your grandma, she made my family very happy and full!

With the exception of adding 1/2 teaspoon of onion powder, I follow this recipe exactly. The flavors and texture are a great combination and the beef/ground pork combo are a must for good authentic taste. Served with mashed potatoes it is definitely a dinner all star.

My husband's post on Facebook says it all:"Growing up with Polish and Lithuanian relatives, and eating at Hungarian restaurants in New Brunswick and Trenton, I've had plenty of authentic stuffed cabbage. But the best ever was last night's dinner, made by my wife on her first attempt using an online recipe. Embarrassed to reveal how many I ate!" I substituted parsley with celery leaves, just because I did not have parsley at the time.
delicious, I used 1 large can of tomato soup and 1 sm. can of tomato sauce! It was a delicious dinner with mashed potatoes!
It was exactly what I wanted. It was easy to make, the instructions were perfect, and it came out great!
I have made these many many times. My family prefers that I use V8 juice instead of the tomato soup base.
This was a bit of work. Our store doesn't stock ground pork, so I bought boneless country ribs and ground it myself. Anyway, it was just like my Polish grandma and mom used to make. Well worth it!
Delicious! My only critique is that it needed more salt. 1/2 tsp. of salt isn't enough for over 3 lbs. of filling.
This is one of the very best cabbage rolls recipes I have ever used. The only thing I do different is I throw half a can of Campbell's tomato soup in with the meat mix.
I loved the sauce. Vinegar and sugar added a nice tang. The meat was very flavorful, yet a little dry. I will definitely make again.

These were very good. I used all ground beef, because that's all I had, and fresh minced garlic and followed rest of the recipe. I took the leaves off the cabbage and boiled them. It took quite a while to make. I rolled them all together and put them in the fridge for the next day. I made the sauce the next day and baked them for an hour and a half.

This is a very good basic recipe, but I did add some things and we really enjoyed it. Giving 4 stars as written. I used brown sugar instead of white and added a couple of tsp of Worcester sauce to the tomato sauce (and doubled the sauce because we like a lot of sauce) I used fresh garlic instead of powder and ground ham as opposed to regular pork. I appreciated the tips for preparing the cabbage leaves. I used about 4 inches of water in the pot which was plenty. I didn't use any of the water to thin the sauce. I also didn't precook the rice, after 2.5 hours in the oven, it was perfectly cooked.

My family & I have found this our favorite dish of all time. We all love it! At 78 Y.Ol, I don't cook a lot but when the mod strikes me they all beg me to make this recipe. They help with boiling & removing cabbage leaves & I finish up. I always triple the recipes so everyone can take leftovers home.

OMG had 10 over for dinner as a thank you to a friend. He asked for stuffed cabbage so I made this receipt, I doubled it to make enough for all. He LOVED it and all who had never tried stuffed cabbaged loved it too. I made it exactly as the recipie shows except I added a little bit of tomato sauce to the meat mixture. Made 29 cabbage leaves and everyone took home leftovers.
make cabbage rolls half the size. 2 Tbsp filling. Use cabbage water. Cover completely. Cook at least 5 hrs

This recipe's ingredients are exactly how I made it with my Hungarian grandmother almost 20 years ago. I made it for my family, I received many compliments from them that the hulapki tasted exactly like the way my grandmother made it. 
Easy recipe to follow, no problems at all.
I plan to use the recipe in the future.
I didn't have ground pork so I just used all lean hamburger. This came out very tasty! Even my picky husband enjoyed it!
Very good! I used sausage in stead of simple ground pork. Gave it more spice. Careful with the vinegar. I used a bit too much but still was delicious
Just like my Mom
Loved this dish! However, instead of tomato sauce, I used crushed tomatoes for a thicker, richer sauce. My Man and I loved it!

This is a family Hungarian traditional meal I grew up on. I added Paprika, celery seed, pepper, salt, cumin, Jsmine rise cooked in a rice cooker, and all spice. 1/2 table spoon for all the spices. Next time I plan to make it with purple cabbage.

What a great recipe! The stuffed cabbage and sauce both have a lot of flavor and this is definitely my go-to recipe from now on. I followed the recipe as is, but I double the sauce. These freeze great also!
this sounds so good! I wonder if anyone has a version that is ok for diabetics (low carbs) minus the sugar and little or no rice ?
